author: Smino97
body:
Hi,

I am trying to run powershell core on a live booted CentOS 7. The NFS of the System is running on a dedicated Server and is read-only that multiple clients can access the NFS at the same time.
I tried the newest versions stable, lts and preview. None of them seem to work on read-only filesystems.

Question is: Is there a way to run Powershell Core on read-only FS, e.g. by manually setting up the environment properly?

# Steps to reproduce

```
1. Setup PXE Server using https://github.com/bertvv/ansible-role-pxeserver
2. Setup NFS using https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/7/html/storage_administration_guide/diskless-nfs-config
3. Install Powershell on the exported NFS with
`sudo yum install powershell --installroot=_exported-root-directory_ --releasever=/`
4. Connect to Live booted client and run `pwsh`

```

# Expected behavior

```
Powershell starts

```

# Actual behavior

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62539851/77311661-d3db1780-6d00-11ea-9d55-a0d5b8731e6a.png)

Extract of `strace -f pwsh-preview`

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62539851/77311764-07b63d00-6d01-11ea-8a68-3e190a5590b8.png)

# Environment data

```
Package installed: powershell-preview-7.0.0_rc.3-1.rhel.7.x86_64.rpm
CentOS 7

```

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body:
**First**, .NET Core runtime creates pipes for managed debugging, when the runtime starts up.
> ... pipes for managed debugging in /tmp. They are named something like “clr-debug-pipe-17206-65823754-out”, “clr-debug-pipe-17206-65823754-in” where 17206 is the process id and 65823754 is the process creation time.

Your screenshot shows the failure of creating the pipes. For details, see https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/7204

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/127450/77346070-dafb2900-6cf2-11ea-9323-9456538ab9a3.png)

This step can be disabled by executing `export COMPlus_EnableDiagnostics=0` before start the .NET Core program. See https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/pull/15878 for details.

**Second**, the update notification feature added in pwsh 7 requires writing to the disk. But you can disable it by executing `export POWERSHELL_UPDATECHECK=Off` before starting pwsh.

**Third**, the `PSReadLine` saves command line history to a file. This can be disabled by running `Set-PSReadLineOption -HistorySaveStyle SaveNothing` right after starting pwsh I guess.

**Fourth**, the module analysis in PowerShell saves the analysis results to a cache file. This cannot be disabled, but the failure of writing to the cache file will be tolerated by pwsh.

**Fifth, ~this one might be a hard blocker.~** pwsh also creates a pipe for debugging purpose when starting (attach to a running pwsh process), and obviously, this will fail on a read-only file system. ~It's very possible this failure will terminate the process.~ Just got @PaulHigin's response on this: `PowerShell still runs if the named pipe cannot be created.  It just won't be able to use IPC.`

### Given above, it's possible to run pwsh on a read-only file system, and you can try it out and share your observations.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body:
The exception happens here, when trying to create the data directory.
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/68442a33e5f775c80526b2f64475c795f6bb085b/src/System.Management.Automation/CoreCLR/CorePsPlatform.cs#L278-L301

It turns out this method attempts to create directories at multiple code paths ...
There could be code like this elsewhere. It was never a target for pwsh to work on read-only file system.

To work around this particular issue, you will have to pre-create those default directories:
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/68442a33e5f775c80526b2f64475c795f6bb085b/src/System.Management.Automation/CoreCLR/CorePsPlatform.cs#L258-L261 
but I doubt if it's worth to try, because you may run into other similar issues after working around this one.
